questions.text: Vascular injury causes intimal thickening by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Vascular injury results in intimal thickening due to smooth muscle proliferation.

Vascular injury stimulates the migration of smooth muscle cells of the tunica media to the tunica intima. These smooth muscle cells proliferate and also synthesize extracellular matrix leading to intimal thickening. This is the stereotypical response of the vessel wall to an injury regardless of the cause of injury.

questions.text: Endothelial dysfunction is implicated in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Endothelial dysfunction is not implicated in aneurysm formation. An aneurysm occurs due to the pathology of connective tissue within the vascular wall.

Endothelial dysfunction is the pathological alteration of the endothelium such that it becomes pro-inflammatory and prothrombogenic. It is caused by various injuries to endothelial cells:

  • Hemodynamic stresses - responsible for vascular pathology in hypertension
  • Lipid products - leading to the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis
  • Advanced glycation end-products (AGE) - responsible for diabetic microangiopathy
  • Viruses, bacterial products, cytokines, and complement components

questions.text: Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
The given image shows arteriosclerosis and calcification in the tunica media, that does not encroach on the vessel lumen. This is suggestive of Monckeberg's medial sclerosis.

Monckeberg's medial sclerosis affects medium-sized muscular arteries and is characterized by calcification of the medial walls of the affected arteries. Adults aged over 50 years are usually affected. 

Arteriosclerosis refers to the thickening of the arterial wall and loss of elasticity. There are four patterns of arteriosclerosis:

  • Small vessel arteriosclerosis - involves small arteries and arterioles
    • It has two variants - hyaline arteriosclerosis, and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis
  • Monckeberg medial sclerosis - involves calcification of the walls of muscular arteries
  • Fibromuscular intimal hyperplasia- usually a healing response to inflammation (eg: arteritis) or mechanical injury (eg: stent insertion)
  • Atherosclerosis - mainly involves elastic and muscular arteries

questions.text: The following incidental finding is seen on a radiograph of a 60-year-old man. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It involves the internal elastic lamina
It involves the external elastic lamina

questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows extensive calcification of the femoral arteries which is suggestive of Monckeberg medial sclerosis. It is characterized by the calcification of the walls of muscular arteries, typically starting along the internal elastic lamina and involves the media of the arteries. 

It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is not associated with hypertension or diabetes. It is usually an incidental finding.

questions.text: Which of the following pathological changes occurs in the small vessels of patients suffering from hypertension?
questions.solution:
Hypertension results in hyaline arteriosclerosis of the small vessels.

Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may lead to arteriosclerosis which is the thickening of the vessel wall. It has two variants which are hyaline arteriosclerosis and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.

In large and medium-sized arteries, hypertension leads to degenerative changes in the vessel walls, leading to:

  • Dissection
  • Aneurysm formation
  • Cerebrovascular hemorrhage
  • Acceleration of atherosclerosis

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis?
questions.solution:
The arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs as a result of plasma protein deposition.

Hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs due to injury to the endothelial cells. This allows plasma protein leakage into the arteriolar wall. The endothelial injury also stimulates increased matrix synthesis by the smooth muscle cells. These lead to the deposition of homogenous pink hyaline material causing the thickening of arteriolar walls.

The given image shows hyaline arteriosclerosis. It occurs in the following conditions:

questions.text: The renal biopsy of a 50-year-old chronic hypertensive patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hyperplastic arteriosclerosis, as noted by the onion-skin appearance of the arteriole. This is seen in malignant nephrosclerosis. 

Nephrosclerosis is caused by sclerosis of the small arteries and the arterioles of the kidney leading to diffuse impairment of renal blood supply. It is of 2 types:

Benign nephrosclerosis Malignant nephrosclerosis 
Seen in benign hypertension Seen in malignant hypertension
Causes hyaline arteriosclerosis Causes hyperplastic arteriosclerosis and fibrinoid necrosis of the arterioles.

The characteristic flea-bitten appearance of the kidney is seen in malignant nephrosclerosis (shown below). This is due to small petechial hemorrhages resulting from the rupture of arterioles.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presented with chest pain. Past history is significant for dyslipidemia and an ischemic stroke 2 years ago. Coronary angiography was performed and showed the following. What is the correct sequence of events leading to this condition?
  1. Platelet adhesion
  2. Accumulation of lipoproteins in vessel wall
  3. Endothelial injury and dysfunction
  4. Monocyte adhesion to endothelium
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery are suggestive of atherosclerosis. It progresses in the following sequence:

  1. Endothelial injury and dysfunction
  2. Accumulation of lipoproteins in the vessel wall
  3. Monocyte adhesion to the endothelium
  4. Platelet adhesion
  5. Factor release from activated platelets, macrophages, and vascular wall cells
  6. Smooth muscle cell proliferation, extracellular matrix production, and recruitment of T cells
  7. Lipid accumulation both extracellularly and within cells
  8. Calcification of ECM and necrotic debris late in the pathogenesis

Hence, atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory and healing response of the arterial wall to endothelial injury. The two most important causes of endothelial injury leading to atherosclerosis are hemodynamic disturbances and hypercholesterolemia.

The image below shows partial occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery.

questions.text: What is the most important independent risk factor for atherosclerosis?
questions.solution:
The most important independent risk factor for atherosclerosis is family history.

The familial predisposition to atherosclerosis is usually polygenic. It is related to the familial clustering of other established risk factors, such as hypertension or diabetes. It may also be due to inherited variations in pathophysiologic processes such as inflammation.

Hyperlipidemia (specifically hypercholesterolemia) is a major risk factor for atherosclerosis. Even in the absence of other risk factors, hypercholesterolemia is sufficient to initiate lesion development.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Atherosclerosis

Nonmodifiable (constitutional):

  • Genetic abnormalities
  • Family history
  • Increasing age
  • Male gender

Modifiable:

  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypertension
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Diabetes

Additional risk factors:

  • Inflammation 
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • Metabolic syndrome
  • Lipoprotein a [Lp(a)] 
  • Elevated plasminogen activator inhibitor 1
  • Type A personality

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of atherosclerosis?
questions.solution:
The most common site of atherosclerosis is the lower abdominal aorta.

In descending order, the most extensively involved vessels in atherosclerosis are:

  • Lower abdominal aorta
  • Coronary arteries
  • Popliteal arteries
  • Internal carotid arteries
  • Arteries of the circle of Willis

questions.text: The autopsy of a 14-year-old boy who died in a motor vehicle accident showed the following lesions on the inner surface of the aorta. What do these lesions indicate?
questions.solution:
The above image shows yellow spots on the inner surface of the aorta, which represent fatty streaks. They indicate a collection of foamy macrophages in the intima of the vessel wall. 

Fatty streaks may be present in the aorta of infants, virtually all adolescents, and even individuals without known risk factors. These lesions are not indicative of atherosclerosis, but some of them may evolve into atheromatous plaques later in life by smooth muscle proliferation and extracellular matrix deposition.

questions.text: Where are the following cells in an atheromatous plaque derived from?
questions.solution:
The cells marked in the image above are the foam cells in atheromatous plaques. They refer to lipid-laden monocytes/ macrophages or smooth muscle cells within the plaques.

These cells ingest lipoproteins accumulated within the intima of the vessel wall. Since these lipoproteins are modified due to the action of inflammatory mediators, they cannot be degraded further within these cells. This leads to the accumulation of modified lipids within these cells converting them to foam cells.

questions.text: In which part of the atheromatous plaque are the T-cells and macrophages in abundance?
questions.solution:
T-cells and macrophages are in abundance in the shoulder of an atheromatous plaque.

Structure of an atherosclerotic plaque:

  • Superficial fibrous cap - made up of smooth muscle cells and connective tissue, especially collagen. It also contains macrophages, foam cells, and lymphocytes. It determines the stability of plaque.
  • Necrotic core - contains lipid (cholesterol and cholesterol esters), debris from dead cells, calcium, and foam cells.
  • Shoulder - a more cellular area containing macrophages, T-cells, and smooth muscle cells.
  • Periphery - shows neovascularization/proliferation of small blood vessels.

The image below shows the structure of an atherosclerotic plaque.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding a stable atherosclerotic plaque?
questions.solution:
A stable atherosclerotic plaque has abundant smooth muscle cells.

These cells synthesize collagen which stabilizes the plaque. Both these features contribute to a thick fibrous cap that prevents the easy rupture of a plaque.

Stable plaque Vulnerable plaque
Dense collagen Less collagen
Thick fibrous cap Thin fibrous cap
Minimal inflammation Increased inflammation
Less extracellular lipid Abundant extracellular lipid
Abundant smooth muscle cells Few smooth muscle cells
Few foam cells Abundant  foam cells

questions.text: In a 50-year-old normotensive patient with a 10-year history of dyslipidemia, which of the following complications is he at the least risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A 50-year-old patient suffering from dyslipidemia for the past 10 years is likely to have atherosclerosis. Dissection is associated with hypertension, not atherosclerosis. 

An atherosclerotic plaque may undergo pathological changes such as:  

  • Thrombus formation -  due to rupture, ulceration, erosion
  • Increase in plaque size - due to hemorrhage into the plaque

These consequences occlude the lumen of the vessel and impair the blood supply. Impaired blood supply may lead to claudication, ischemic heart disease, myocardial infarction, cerebral infarction, or even gangrene.

The thrombus may dislodge and cause an embolism. Atherosclerotic debris released due to plaque rupture may produce microemboli, known as atheroembolism.

Atherosclerotic plaques also cause ischemic atrophy of the underlying media. This causes weakness of the vessel wall leading to aneurysm formation.

The image below depicts the late complications of atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A patient with anginal chest pain is planned for coronary angiography. What level of stenosis would you expect to see in the affected artery?
questions.solution:
This symptomatic patient likely has >70% occlusion of his coronary arteries. This is known as critical stenosis. 

It refers to the stage at which the occlusion is sufficiently severe to produce tissue ischemia. This leads to clinical manifestations of ischemia such as:

  • Stable angina
  • Bowel ischemia
  • Intermittent claudication

questions.text: Elevated levels of which of the following is not a predictor for stroke?
questions.solution:
Elevated plasminogen levels are not associated with stroke. Elevated levels of the following are predictors for stroke: 

  • C-reactive protein - also indicates risk for MI, PAD and used to monitor effectiveness of risk reduction measures like exercise, weight loss
  • Homocysteine - also correlates with MI, PAD, venous thrombosis, and premature vascular disease
  • Plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 - marker of hemostatic and/or fibrinolytic function and also predicts risk of MI

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of heart failure. He had undergone a coronary bypass procedure with a small-diameter graft 3 weeks ago.  What is the likely cause for his presentation?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of an early failure of a small diameter venous graft (≤8 mm). The likely mechanism for graft failure within the 1st month is acute thrombosis.

Late vein graft failure (after months to years) is due to:

  • Neointimal hyperplasia (1 month to 1 year)
  • Atherosclerotic plaque (> 1 year)
  • Aneurysm 

Based on the diameter of the synthetic or autologous vascular graft, it can be:

  • Large diameter graft (12-18mm) -
    • Used in high-flow locations such as the aorta
  • Small diameter graft (≤8 mm) -
    • Includes saphenous vein or left internal mammary artery
    • Used in coronary bypass surgeries

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the KLF-2 transcription factor?

choices.text: Production is induced by laminar blood flow
Responsible for the atheroprotective role of statins

questions.solution:
Kruppel like factor-2 (KLF-2) is responsible for turning off the inflammatory gene transcription.

KLF-2 production is induced by laminar blood flow which is seen in normal endothelium. This transcription factor activates the atheroprotective genes and turns off inflammatory gene transcription. Statins up-regulate KLF-2 expression in endothelial cells, and this activity is associated with an anti-inflammatory phenotype.

Up-regulation of KLF-2 gene expression may be a novel strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis.
